full_text:
Dr. Richard G. Lynch
Dr. Richard Lynch rccuived his B.A. degree in Zoology.
University of Missouri, and his M.D. degree from the
University of Rochester  1966. Fallowing graduation
from medical school, Dick joincd cur training program
in anatomic and experimenta! pathology. During this
period of training. Dic became interestd in te fld
of cancer immunology. In order to obtair the basic
expertise required to work in this field, he crained for
two years under the direction of one of the mosl out-
standing immunochemists in the worid—Dr. Herman
Eisen. previous Chairman. Deparrment of Microbiology.
Washington University Medical School.
that immunization of animals with specific myeloma
While working with Dr. Eisen, Dick discovered
proteins would inhibi: the growth of myelora tumor
led to a continuing series of .nvestigations on the
mechanism of innibition of growth of the neoplasms in
the immunizea animals.
In collaborative studies with Dr. Gerald Medoff,
Department of Mecicine, Washington University School
of Medicine. Dick demons:rated that the antitumor
effects of amphotericin B were in part cue to the
production of antibodies to the tumor ir the treated
animals. These investigations demonstrated that
leukemic cells wouid survive in the central nervous
system of those animals since tho antibodics could not
destroy the tumor cells in this privileged site. This
animal model is directly appticable to human leukemias
and provides an cxolanatior of this phenomoron in man
as well as providing a model to devise a means of
eradicatung the necplastic cells remaining in the central
nervous system.
In recent studies. Dick has devekoped techniques
which indicate that myeloma tumor cells may uncergo
ditferentiation from primitive ce Is to mature cells which
produce specific immunoglob lins. These fundarrontal
findings are of direct importance in unde'standing the
